1) Money serve three main purposes:

2) Financial system.
 a. Lenders

 d. Capital - the machinery, tools and factories owned by a business and used in production.
 e. Financial system is a network of institutions, markets and contracts that brings lenders and borrowers together. 
 f. Debt - if you get a loan from the bank, you are obligated to pay back the amount you borrowed plus the amount of interest.
 g. Equity - the difference between the value of the assets/ interest and the cost of liabilities of something owned.
 h. Financial instrument - a tradeable asset of any kind.
 i. Financial institution - an establishment that conducts financial transactions such as investments, loans and deposits.

Those only use barter when dealing (rarely) with total strangers - if there's any level of mutual trust within a community, they just figure someone will get them back at some point.

text: Let us note that a Barter Economy never existed.  Barter happens, but it has never been the basis for any economy that we know of. text:
+Hooya2 But the point is that now there is $271 that can be spent.


We basically have a dual currency system: paper dollars (PD) and bank credits (BC). Banks can't fiddle with PD but they control BC (restricted by reserve requirements). The main problem is that in our modern society, we all accept BC as PD. Banks basically supplanted PD with BC, which makes BC the de facto currency and BC creation de facto money creation (even  though no PD is created).


Another quirk of fractional reserve banking is that creation of addition BC dilutes the real value of each individual BC, and since we accept BC as PD, the real value of PD also goes down. So the additional purchasing power from the new BC comes from all existing BC+PD, which then the banks charge interest on. And that's kind of funny; it's like I can charge a fee to lend out your money to other people. Profitable business.﻿

+Hooya2 If the first guy spends his money electronically then everything happens within the banking system and no PD is involved.
PD and BC are not interchangeable, hence bank runs can happen. But what's the biggest purchase you've made in cash? The only way the banks can be caught with their pants down is for people to demand billions of dollars in paper. Until that happens, BC is PD.
Also note, all American bills say "Federal Reserve Note", which is already a bank credit for the Federal Reserve.﻿

+Hooya2 My point is functional equivalence: FRC behaves like PD in every way, so whether PD exists physically is irrelevant.
PD and BC are technically not functionally equivalent, but no single person can make them behave differently at a bank, so to any individual BC is equivalent to PD. And that's the source of the problem: banks essentially created a new currency which they can freely* issue themselves.
If a bank has two clients, then one client can transfer any amount of BC to the other client, regardless of PD the bank has.
Q: Do you know how much money in your bank account is PD and how much is BC?﻿

+Hooya2 Suppose there is one bank and two people A and B. A has $1000(PD) and wants to buy a car from B for $5000. A can deposit $1000(PD) into the bank, borrow $4000(BC) from the bank and transfer $5000(BC) to B's account in exchange for the car. Now the bank has $1000(PD), A has a car plus $4000 of debt and B has $5000(BC). A $5000 purchase occurred even though only $1000(PD) existed.


Also the $4000 debt is not the same as $-4000(BC). Imagine A found a rock and sold it to B for $100(BC), then A would have $100(BC) and $4000 of debt, which is different from $3900 of debt. With $100(BC) and $4000 of debt, A can still buy erasers from B, but $3900 of debt can't buy anything.


When people take out loans, they rarely get it as PD. If they did, banks would be more careful about giving out mortgages.






Whether BC mimics PD is key in "money" creation. Banks create BC, money is PD*. So if BC behaves enough like PD and people accept it as such, then it's de facto money creation.


BC can also mimic PD even when PD moves because there are enough people that the PD deposits and withdrawals fluctuate well within the banks' reserve requirements.﻿

+Hooya2 The Fed keeps accounts for banks, not individuals. In my example, there is only one (commercial) bank, hence the Fed doesn't apply. The Fed can't control what a commercial bank does with its own credits.
Or are you saying now that commercial bank accounts contain FRC?﻿

+Hooya2 One step at a time, so you agree that with one bank, loans create "money".


While I believe you, I would like to see references citing the value of interbank loans and intrabank loans supporting your claim of "Bank-to-bank transactions are by far the most common type of loans".﻿

+Hooya2 If by "money" you mean PD, then of course BC is not "money", but it has the same effect.

Imagine a static economy; an increase in PD supply is equivalent to a corresponding devaluation of PD, or things getting more expensive. If there is a single bank and it issues new BC and everyone accepts BC as payment, then clearly things will cost more BC. Since you can only exchange 1PD for 1BC, things are more expensive, which has the same effect as printing more PD.

As for having multiple banks which deal with each other in PD, all you need is scale. In a model where bank clients uniformly select other bank clients and sends that person a random amount of money (with or without loans), for any pair of banks, the mean net PD transfer is 0 and more importantly the variance of the net PD transfer decreases with the number of transactions. In the long term, the amount of PD each bank holds remains constant, while still being able to issue more BC. And in that case having a network of banks which essentially has no net PD transfer between any pair, is equivalent to each bank only serving its own bubble of clients.

Does your common sense tell you anything else is "by far the most" something?﻿
